I've been encouraged to learn ReactJS, and I learn best when I have a project. 

If you have a smart TV, you might have looked at the apps available, and you may have noticed some snow/christmas/winter app. This has snow fall, snowmen, pine trees etc. You're meant to have it on the TV while you have your mulled whatever. 

I felt like this was something I could make with the Web Platform&trade; and utilise React. Not sure I'm really using the benefits of React, but making this has helped familiarise me with the way it works. 

Anyway - to the point; I've decided to blog about how I went about making the Winter Scene. You can see the current version running on [Glitch](https://winter-scene.glitch.me), and view the code on [my github repo](https://github.com/underscoredotspace/winter-scene). It's not displaying correctly on Safari or IE, but I'm sure we can fix that in time for next winter. 

![Screenshot of winter-scene](data:image/png;base64,)

The first part introduced me to drawing with SVG, and was way easier than I'd expected. 

## Stars
The stars are SVG polygons, drawn from co-ordinates based on the size given. 

<svg class="star" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" style="width: 30px; height: 30px;" viewBox="0 0 30 30"><polygon class="star" fill="yellow" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" points="0,10.00 30,10.00 5.00,30 15.00,0 25,30"</polygon></svg>

The polygon is drawn out like the below, starting from the middle at the very top - `{x:w/2, y:0}`. 

![](data:image/png;base64,)

For a star 30 pixels high, we create the co-ordinates for the SVG polygon that go in the `points` attribute. 

```
<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" 
  style="width: 30px; height: 30px;"
  viewBox="0 0 30 30">

  <polygon xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" 
    points="0,10.00 30,10.00 5.00,30 15.00,0 25,30"
    fill="yellow">
  </polygon>

</svg>
```

It's really that simple. 

## React code
As I mentioned at the start, I want to familiarise myself with ReactJS, so the `Star` is a component, with a `Stars` parent. 

```
import React from 'react'
const SVGNS = 'http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'
const rnd = (min, max) => Math.floor(Math.random() * (max - min + 1) + min)

export default class Stars extends React.Component {
    state = {stars: []}
    
    makeStars = () => {
      this.width = this.node.clientWidth
      this.height = this.node.clientHeight
      this.starDensity = this.height * this.width / 7000
      
      let stars = []
      
      for (let ndx = 0; ndx < this.starDensity; ndx++) {
        stars.push({
          x: rnd(-30, this.width),
          y: rnd(-30, this.height-30),
          size: rnd(15, 30),
          cycleTime: rnd(5, 20),
          rotation: rnd(0, 359)
        })
      }
      
      this.setState({stars})
    }
  
    componentDidMount = () => {
       window.addEventListener("resize", this.makeStars)
       this.makeStars()
    }
  
    render = () =>(
      <div className="star-field" ref={n=>(this.node=n)}>
        {this.state.stars.map((star, ndx) => (
          <Star {...star} key={`star-${ndx}`} />
        ))}
      </div>
    )
  }
  
  class Star extends React.Component {
    constructor(props) {
      super(props)
      const s = props.size
  
      const starStyle = {
        top: `${props.y}px`,
        left: `${props.x}px`,
        width: `${s}px`,
        height: `${s}px`,
        transform: `rotate(${props.rotation}deg)`,
        animation: `twinkle ${props.cycleTime}s infinite`
      }
  
      const points = `0,${(s / 3).toFixed(2)} 
        ${s},${(s / 3).toFixed(2)} 
        ${(s / 6).toFixed(2)},${s} 
        ${(s / 2).toFixed(2)},0 
        ${s - (s / 6).toFixed(2)},${s}`
  
      this.state = {
        points,
        starStyle,
        vb: `0 0 ${this.props.size} ${this.props.size}`
      }
    }
  
    render = ()  => (
      <svg className="star" xmlns={SVGNS} style={this.state.starStyle} viewBox={this.state.vb}>
        <polygon className="star" xmlns={SVGNS} points={this.state.points} />
      </svg>
    )
  }
```
